channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Olympic Gymnast Suni Lee Overcame Stalkers, Kidney Disease and Doubt
item.description: Sunisa Lee, the all-around women’s champion at the Tokyo Olympics, overcame personal strife, family expectations and serious illness to get to Paris.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sunisa Lee was a quiet 18-year-old from a conservative Hmong community in Minnesota. Then she won a gold medal at the Tokyo Olympics.

item.title: U.S. and Other Countries Denounce Venezuela Election Results
item.description: The United States and many Latin American countries said President Nicolás Maduro cannot claim victory without the full release of vote counts.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: People waiting outside a polling station in Caracas on Sunday night for news of the results.

item.title: African National Congress Expels Former President Jacob Zuma
item.description: The African National Congress party severed ties with its former leader over his decision to become the leading voice of an opposition party in the last election, calling its platform “dangerous.”
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Jacob Zuma, the former president of South Africa, campaigning ahead of the South African elections in May.

item.title: Why Some Olympic Swimmers Think About Math in the Pool
item.description: In a sport where gold and silver can be separated by a fraction of a second, many of the world’s top swimmers now scour data for even the smallest edge.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Vrentas
item.media:description: Kate Douglass of the United States often wears a device in training that measures her movement through the water.

item.title: Sinead O’Connor Died of Pulmonary Disease and Asthma, Death Report Says
item.description: A death certificate filed last week revealed the natural causes behind the death last July of Ms. O’Connor, the Irish singer and activist.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Ellius Grace for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sinead O’Connor in 2021. In January, a coroner said that Ms. O’Connor had died of “natural causes” but did not provide details.

item.title: Is the Seine Clean Enough? Olympic Triathletes Wait on Testers.
item.description: Water-quality results recorded before dawn on Tuesday will determine if the men’s triathlon race will take place hours later.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A $1.53 billion project to clean up the Seine in time for the Olympics has come down to a last-second water-quality test.

item.title: Here’s What to Know About Venezuela’s Flawed Election
item.description: Stark irregularities and suppression efforts could plunge the country back into instability and economic decline.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Polling station workers in Petare, Venezuela, moved outside as they faced challenges in the transmission of votes during the election on Sunday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Olha Kharlan Wins Bronze in Fencing at Olympics
item.description: The war has torn apart old alliances in fencing, and heightened the acrimony between Russia and Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman
item.media:description: Olha Kharlan of Ukraine celebrated after defeating Sebin Choi of Korea on Monday to win the bronze medal.

item.title: Huw Edwards, Former BBC Anchor, Charged With Making Indecent Images of Children
item.description: Huw Edwards, who led the BBC’s coverage of major events, including King Charles III’s coronation, has been charged with three offenses, the police said on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Huw Edwards speaking in London in 2020. Mr. Edwards, 62, presented the BBC’s flagship 10 o’clock evening newscast and led the broadcaster’s coverage of major national events.

item.title: Man Detained in France After Entering Rail Site Near Rouen
item.description: The man was picked up near Rouen days after arsonists damaged train signaling cables around the country, but he is not a suspect in that case, prosecutors say.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.category: SNCF (Societe Nationale des Chemins de fer Francais)
item.media:description: Railway employees and police officers inspecting the scene of a suspected attack last week on the high-speed rail network in Croiselles, northern France.

item.title: Is the Olympic Flame Real?
item.description: Two torches may have lit it to open the Paris Games, but that’s not a fire in the cauldron.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Keh
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times

item.title: Anguish in Golan Heights Village After Rocket Strike From Lebanon
item.description: A stunned hush of collective mourning fell over Majdal Shams, in the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights, after the attack from Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents gather on the soccer field in Majdal Shams on Sunday following the rocket attack that killed 12 children.

item.title: Southport Stabbing: 2 Children Killed and More Injured in Attack in U.K.
item.description: A 17-year-old was arrested after an assault that left two children dead and nine children and two adults injured. The police said it did not appear terrorism-related.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Police officers at the scene of stabbings in Southport, England, on Monday.

item.title: Simone Biles Is Done Being Judged
item.description: Three years after she dropped out of the Tokyo Games with a mental block, she is back at the Olympics with a defiant attitude — and a sense of where she is in the air.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Simone Biles performing on the balance beam in Tokyo in 2021.

item.title: El Chapo’s Son Abducted El Mayo and Flew Him to U.S., Officials Now Say
item.description: U.S. officials say Joaquín Guzmán López, a son of El Chapo, forced Ismael Zambada García onto a plane bound for Texas, in a case that landed the two Sinaloa cartel leaders in custody last week.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico at a news conference following the arrest of Ismael Zambada García. Mr. Zambada García’s lawyer has said his client was kidnapped by Joaquín Guzmán López, El Chapo’s son.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Less Than 100 Days to Go
item.description: Plus, results in Venezuela’s tainted election and the new math of swimming.
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser
item.media:description: Kamala Harris said that she would select a running mate by Aug. 7.

item.title: Aides in Congress Create Dissent Channel to Protest Support for Israel
item.description: An anonymous group of junior staff members has modeled its effort on an internal State Department messaging system, hoping to create an outlet for calls for a cease-fire in the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Maya C. Miller
item.media:description: Protests near the Capitol last week while Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel spoke to a joint meeting of Congress. A group of staff aides organized a pro-Palestinian walkout on Capitol Hill the same day.

item.title: Israeli Troops Held for Questioning in Prisoner Abuse Investigation
item.description: At least nine reservists were detained at a military base holding thousands of Gazans, prompting ultranationalists to break into the base in protest.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Johnatan Reiss and Gabby Sobelman
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: The entrance to the Sde Teiman base in the Negev desert, Israel, in May.

item.title: How a Crisis for Vultures Led to a Human Disaster: Half a Million Deaths
item.description: The birds were accidentally poisoned in India. New research on what happened next shows how wildlife collapse can be deadly for people.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: A vulture in northern India, in 2020. A drug given to cattle in the 1990s nearly wiped out the birds in South Asia.

item.title: Olympics Opening Ceremony Singer Redefines What It Means to Be French
item.description: Aya Nakamura, the French Malian singer, did more than open the Games. She redefined what it means to be French.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Aya Nakamura, center, at the Olympics opening ceremony in Paris on Friday. The choice for her to perform prompted fierce debates over identity and language.

item.title: Erdogan Says Turkey Could Enter Israel to Help Palestinians
item.description: It was unclear whether the comments reflected any concrete plans, but they drew a strong response from Israel.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.media:description: It was unclear whether comments by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, referring to the possibility that his country could enter Israel, reflected concrete plans.

item.title: Are Electric Cars Worth the Money?
item.description: They can be, but it depends on your driving habits. We break it down for you.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: People near a soccer field in the Israeli-controlled town of Majdal Shams, a day after a rocket from Lebanon struck the site on Saturday.

item.title: Maduro Is Declared Winner in Tainted Venezuela Election
item.description: The result, which would give Nicolás Maduro six more years as president, was disputed by the opposition, and the United States said it had “serious concerns.”
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Frances Robles and Julie Turkewitz
item.media:description: President Nicolas Maduro addressing supporters gathered outside the Miraflores presidential palace after electoral authorities declared him the winner of the presidential election in Caracas, Venezuela, on Monday.

item.title: Monday Briefing: A Deadly Strike on the Israel-Lebanon Border
item.description: Plus, Venezuela’s election and the Olympics’ first weekend
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: The site of a rocket strike at a soccer field in the Golan Heights yesterday.

item.title: By the smallest of margins, Torri Huske beat her U.S. teammate and managed to heal an old heartbreak at the same time.
item.description: In third place at the turn, Huske powered to gold, edging her teammate — and world-record holder — Gretchen Walsh at the end by touching just ahead of her.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel, Daniel Berehulak and James Hill
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times

item.title: 12 Officials Sentenced for Roles in Devastating Libya Flood
item.description: The officials were punished nearly a year after two dams above the seaside city of Derna failed in a storm, killing thousands and destroying much of the area.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: Buildings that were destroyed last September in Derna, Libya, after two aging dams collapsed.

item.title: Behind a French roar, Léon Marchand leaves the world’s best swimmers in his wake.
item.description: Marchand, who has been dubbed the “French Michael Phelps,” set the Olympic record in the men’s 400-meter individual medley final.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel, Daniel Berehulak and James Hill

item.title: It’s really a matter of math …
item.description: There are 10,000 athletes at the Paris Games, spread across 32 sports. In the space of 19 days, that field has to be whittled down to just 329 gold medals. So, ultimately, someone has to go out first.

item.title: An Olympics Scene Draws Scorn. Did It Really Parody ‘The Last Supper’?
item.description: Some church leaders and politicians have condemned the performance from the opening ceremony for mocking Christianity. Art historians are divided.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: A screen showing Philippe Katerine's performance during the Olympics’ opening ceremony in Paris on Friday.

item.title: Negotiators Meet to Revive Push for Hostage Release and Cease-Fire in Gaza
item.description: The talks in Rome remain stuck over several key issues, including the extent to which Israeli troops should withdraw from Gaza, where tens of thousands were forced under Israeli orders to evacuate Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: An Israeli armored personnel carrier near the Israeli-Gaza border, as seen from southern Israel, in June.

item.title: The Olympics Has a Bad Guy: Anyone in an Argentina Jersey
item.description: Grudges from the World Cup and rugby union have spilled over to the Games. But is this new sports feud even real?
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith and James Wagner
item.media:description: French spectators booed at a boat carrying Argentina’s Olympic team during the opening ceremony on Friday. There are different explanations for the antipathy.

item.title: U.S. and Japan Strengthen Military Ties
item.description: The two governments said the moves were a response to growing aggression by China, whose rapid military buildup has many leaders worried.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: From left, Lloyd J. Austin III, the U.S. secretary of defense; Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state; Yoko Kamikawa, the Japanese foreign minister; and Minoru Kihara, the Japanese defense minister, at a news conference in Tokyo on Sunday.

item.title: Here’s how Simone Biles and her American teammates stormed into the finals.
item.description: Biles needed tape on her lower leg after an awkward landing, but went on to a solid qualifying performance.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor, Chang W. Lee and Gabriela Bhaskar
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: As F-16s Arrive, Ukraine Still Faces Steep Challenges in the Skies
item.description: Ukraine wants to deploy its first F-16 jets this summer, hoping to counter Russia’s dominance in the air. But stepped-up Russian bombing attacks on air bases complicate the effort.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of a strike on Kyiv’s main children’s hospital earlier this month. Russia’s attacks have become increasingly sophisticated and hard to counter.

item.title: A Blood Test Accurately Diagnosed Alzheimer’s 90% of the Time, Study Finds
item.description: It was much more accurate than primary care doctors using cognitive tests and CT scans. The findings could speed the quest for an affordable and accessible way to diagnose patients with memory problems.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:description: A colored transmission electron micrograph of the nerve cell of the brain of a patient with Alzheimer’s disease showing aggregates of the protein tau in green. The study used a blood test that focuses on a form of that protein.

item.title: Hourslong Lines as Voters Surge to Polls in Venezuela’s Pivotal Election
item.description: Sunday’s vote could end a generation of control by Venezuela’s socialist party. It could also usher in a period of profound uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Frances Robles and Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: A long line outside a polling station in Caracas, Venezuela, on Sunday as people voted in what promises to be a watershed election.

item.title: Russia Punches Through Weakened Lines in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: Military analysts say Russian forces are increasingly investigating Ukrainian lines to identify weakened positions before attacking and breaking through.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A soldier fired a howitzer toward Russian troops in the eastern Donetsk region this month. Ukrainian forces are strained by relentless Russian attacks along a more than 600-mile front.

item.title: Israel Hits Lebanon in Overnight Strikes After Soccer Field Attack
item.description: Diplomats were scrambling to prevent a surge in fighting, officials said, after Israel retaliated for the rocket fire that killed at least 12 children and teenagers in an Israeli-controlled town.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Euan Ward and Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: A soccer field that was hit by a rocket, killing multiple children and teenagers, in the Druze town of Majdal Shams in the Golan Heights in northern Israel on Sunday.

item.title: Echoes of the Fort McMurray Disaster as Fire Sweeps Into Jasper, Alberta
item.description: About a third of the buildings in the mountain resort town have burned, raising questions about preparedness and the role of climate change.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: The Fort McMurray wildfire melted almunium in cars and trucks that were caught in the blaze

item.title: How Katie Ledecky Won Bronze in the 400-meter Freestyle
item.description: Ledecky won her 11th Olympic medal, but was outpaced by Ariarne Titmus of Australia.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel, Chang W. Lee and Gabriela Bhaskar
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times

item.title: At Least 12 Killed in Rocket Attack From Lebanon in Golan Heights
item.description: It was the deadliest single attack from across Israel’s northern border in months of hostilities. Israel blamed Hezbollah, which denied responsibility.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Emergency workers at the scene after a rocket fired from Lebanon struck a soccer field in Majdal Shams, a village in the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights, on Saturday.

item.title: ‘All We Think of Is Him’: Putting Names and Faces to Bangladesh Carnage
item.description: The partial lifting of a communications blackout is providing a picture of the young victims of a brutal crackdown on protesters. Thousands of others have been swept into jails.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Saif Hasnat
item.media:description: A daughter consoling her mother, who broke into tears after receiving the body of her son at a morgue in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Monday. Nearly 200 protesters have been killed in a crackdown by government forces, according to estimates.

item.title: Blinken and a Top Chinese Official in Talks on U.S.-China Tensions
item.description: The U.S. secretary of state pressed China’s top foreign policy official on Beijing’s support for Russia’s efforts to rebuild its military industries during the Ukraine war.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, met his Chinese counterpart, Wang Yi, in Vientiane, Laos, on Saturday.

item.title: Your Guide to Olympic Gymnastics: Vault
item.description: Want to follow the women’s gymnastics competition in Paris, but don’t understand the skills or how they’re scored? Here’s a guide.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Rebeca Andrade became the first Brazilian to win an Olympic medal in women’s gymnastics when she earned gold in Tokyo in 2021.

item.title: Your Guide to Olympic Gymnastics: Floor Exercise
item.description: Want to follow the women’s gymnastics competition in Paris, but don’t understand the skills or how they’re scored? Here’s a guide.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Simone Biles of the United States on her way to winning a gold medal in floor exercise at the 2016 Olympics in Rio.

item.title: South Korea Reports Leak From a Top Intelligence Agency
item.description: It’s highly unusual for the nation’s authorities to publicly acknowledge a leak from the command​, which is one of South Korea’s top two spy agencies.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Looking at the North Korean side of the border from the unification observatory in Paju, South Korea, in June.

item.title: Your Guide to Olympic Gymnastics: Uneven Bars
item.description: Want to follow the women’s gymnastics competition in Paris, but don’t understand the skills or how they’re scored? Here’s a guide.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: American gymnast Sunisa Lee won bronze in the uneven bars at the Tokyo Olympics in 2021.

item.title: Your Guide to Olympic Gymnastics: Balance Beam
item.description: Want to follow the women’s gymnastics competition in Paris, but don’t understand the skills or how they’re scored? Here’s a guide.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:description: Lauren Hernandez of the United States competing on the balance beam at the 2016 Olympics in Rio.

item.title: New Israeli Evacuation Order in Gaza Displaces Palestinians Again
item.description: The order affected part of southern Gaza, while farther north, the Israeli military struck the grounds of a school it said was being used by Hamas, killing more than 30 people, Gaza officials said.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Injured Palestinians being taken to a hospital in Khan Younis, in southern Gaza, on Saturday.

item.title: Chinese Swimmer Zhang Yufei Makes First Comments on Doping Case
item.description: Zhang Yufei, one of 23 athletes who tested positive for a banned substance before the last Olympics, said China did not allow doping, and offered a window into the stress the accusations have caused.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Vrentas
item.media:description: China’s Zhang Yufei qualified for the semifinals of the 100-meter butterfly on Saturday morning.

item.title: Here’s What Global Leaders Say About Kamala Harris
item.description: Heads of state and diplomats who have interacted with the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee say she uses humor, and talk of food, to help leaven hard discussions.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris arriving in Indianapolis after a flight aboard Air Force Two on Wednesday.

item.title: More Trains, but Few Answers, After Railway Sabotage in France
item.description: France’s national railway company said traffic was gradually returning to normal a day after arsonists disrupted three high-speed rail lines. But who was behind the attacks remains mysterious.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Aurelien Breeden
item.category: SNCF (Societe Nationale des Chemins de fer Francais)
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: What to Know About Kamala Harris’s Foreign Policy Positions
item.description: Here is what we know about the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee’s views on issues like migration and the wars in Ukraine and Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris speaking during her first campaign rally, in Milwaukee, on Tuesday after she began her run to be the Democratic nominee for president.

item.title: Away From the War in Gaza, Another Palestinian Economy Is Wrecked
item.description: With the closure of checkpoints, Israeli Arabs cannot come to Jenin and Tulkarm to shop, and West Bank Palestinians cannot leave to work in Israel, cutting incomes and building militancy.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Sergey Ponomarev
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Covering up the wall of a house that was damaged after an Israeli raid in the Jenin refugee camp in June.

item.title: ‘No One to Talk To’: The Lingering Trauma of Russian Rape in Ukraine
item.description: Prosecutors in Ukraine are pursuing cases of sexual assault by Russian soldiers, but survivors say more financial and psychological support is needed.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Ada Petriczko
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I had to somehow deal with it on my own,” said Daria, who said she was raped twice by Russian soldiers.

item.title: Léon Marchand: The French Swimmer Who Is Carrying His Country on His Back
item.description: Léon Marchand, who has the potential to win medals in four individual events, bears much of the weight of France’s expectations. He is ready, he said, but added, “It does feel weird.”
item.dc:creator: Jenny Vrentas
item.media:description: Léon Marchand practicing in the Olympics competition pool at the Paris La Défense Arena a few days before the start of the Games.

item.title: Snoop Dogg, NBC’s New Voice of the People
item.description: The network hired the rapper for an expanded role on its broadcasts of the Summer Games in Paris after posting record-low viewership of the Tokyo competition.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Eiffel Tower posing behind a noted American landmark.

item.title: Doused by Rain, Paris Opens Its Games With a Boat Party on the Seine
item.description: Undeterred by arson attacks on rail lines earlier in the day, the Parade of Nations continued beneath a glittering Eiffel Tower, where Celine Dion belted out a love anthem.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: The Eiffel Tower emitted beams of light during the climax of the opening ceremony.
